poem:
"Stages of Stardom"

Bound by our own bindings, we turn,
Round and round like a Broadway marquee,
Yearning for the face to match the name.
Stars, we say, sprinkled on the theater's night,
Yet it's a carousel, ever spinning,
Chasing after constellations of fame.
And who's to argue with the edge of attraction,
When our hearts are filled with their refracted light?
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Slave Play writer criticises star casting but Kit Harington to feature in West End run The writer of Slave Play, the controversial Broadway production about race and sexuality that caused protests and broke Tony nomination records, has criticised commercial theatre’s dependency on casting celebrities, saying it turns performances into a “Disney World attraction”. Jeremy O Harris said star casting – hiring big-name TV, film and even social media stars to perform in the West End". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
